  41      """ 
  42      like str()  but calls str() recursively for lists and tuples 
  43      """ 
  44      import types, string #, __builtin__ 
  45      if type(a) is types.UnicodeType: 
  46          return "u'"+a+"'" 
  47      if type(a) is types.StringType: 
  48          return "'"+a+"'" 
  49      if type(a) is types.TupleType: 
  50          return '(' + string.join(map(myStr,a), ', ') +')'

  52          return '[' + string.join(map(myStr,a), ', ') +']'

  54          return a.name  # 20060720

 246 -def _getGoodifiedArray(arr): 

 247      """ 
 248      return "well behaved" version of a numpy array 
 249      1) convert lists or tuple to numpy-array 
 250      2) make copy of numpy arrays if non-contigous or non-native 
 251      3) convert(relabel) dtype=bool to dtype=uint8 (arr.view(N.uint8)) 
 252      (used in conjunction with SWIGed functions) 
 253      """ 
 254      try: 
 255          if arr.dtype.isnative: 
 256              arr = N.ascontiguousarray(arr) 
 257          else: 
 258              arr = N.ascontiguousarray(arr, arr.dtype.newbyteorder('=')) 
 259      except AttributeError: 
 260              arr = N.ascontiguousarray(arr) 
 261   
 262      if arr.dtype == N.bool:  # no SWIGed function for bool, use uint8 
 263          arr = arr.view(N.uint8) 
 264   
 265      return arr

 295 -def timeIt(execStr, nReps=1, useTime=False): 

 296      """ 
 297      calls exec(execStr)  nReps times 
 298      returns "cpu-time-after"-"cpu-time-before" 
 299      if nReps > 1  the it calls it nReps times 
 300                    and return mmms over all (each separately timed!) 
 301   
 302      if useTime is False: use time.clock() as timer 
 303      if useTime is a callable: use this as time 
 304      otherwise: use time.time() 
 305      NOTE: on Unix time.clock() gives CPU time, time.time() wall time 
 306            on Windows both are wall time (time.time() ONLY at 1ms resolution) 
 307            http://stackoverflow.com/questions/85451/python-time-clock-vs-time-time-accuracy 
 308      """ 
 309      import sys, time 
 310      global fr,fc, argsn, args 
 311      fr = sys._getframe(1) 
 312      # fc = fr.f_code 
 313      #gs = fr.f_locals   #gs = fr.f_globals 
 314       
 315      if not callable(useTime): 
 316          if useTime: 
 317              useTime = time.time 
 318          else: 
 319              useTime = time.clock 
 320   
 321      if nReps==1: 
 322          t0 = useTime() 
 323          exec execStr in fr.f_locals, fr.f_globals 
 324          return useTime() - t0 
 325      else: 
 326          _ttt = N.empty(shape=nReps, dtype=N.float64) 
 327          for _i in range(nReps): 
 328              t0 = useTime() 
 329              exec execStr  in fr.f_locals, fr.f_globals 
 330              _ttt[_i] = useTime() - t0 
 331          return mmms(_ttt)

 413 -def strTranslate(s, frm='', to='', delete='', keep=None): 

 414      """ 
 415      translate chars in string `s` 
 416      each `c` in `frm` is translated into the respective `c` in `to` 
 417        (`to` can be length 1) 
 418      each `c` in `keep` is kept 
 419       UNLESS(!) it is also in `delete` 
 420      each `c` in `delete` is taken out 
 421   
 422      seb: instead of a class we have a function - ref. ASPN/Cookbook/Python/Recipe/303342 
 423   
 424      This class handles the three most common cases where I find myself having to stop and think about how to use translate: 
 425   
 426      1) Keeping only a given set of characters. 
 427      >>> strTranslate('Chris Perkins : 224-7992', keep=U.string.digits) 
 428      '2247992' 
 429   
 430      2) Deleting a given set of characters. 
 431      >>> strTranslate('Chris Perkins : 224-7992', delete=U.string.digits) 
 432      'Chris Perkins : -' 
 433   
 434      3) Replacing a set of characters with a single character. 
 435      >>> trans = Translator(string.digits, '%') 
 436      >>> strTranslate('Chris Perkins : 224-7992', (string.digits, '%') 
 437      'Chris Perkins : %%%-%%%%' 
 438   
 439      Note that the delete parameter trumps the keep parameter if they overlap: 
 440      >>> strTranslate('abcdef', delete='abcd', keep='cdef') 
 441      'ef' 
 442      This is an arbitrary design choice - makes as much sense as anything, I suppose. 
 443      """ 
 444      allchars = string.maketrans('','') 
 445      if len(to) == 1: 
 446          to = to * len(frm) 
 447      trans = string.maketrans(frm, to) 
 448      if keep is not None: 
 449          delete = allchars.translate(allchars, keep.translate(allchars, delete)) 
 450      #def callable(s): 
 451   
 452      if type(s) is unicode: # HACK workaround for unicode (occurred with TextCrtl unicode-version of wxPython) 
 453          s = str(s) 
 454      return s.translate(trans, delete) 

 455      #return callable

4195          return '\n'.join(result)
